heading.title: PART 28 SEPARATE DECISION OF QUESTIONS AND CONSOLIDATION [rr 28.1 –28.5]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 28 SEPARATE DECISION OF QUESTIONS AND CONSOLIDATION [rr 28.1 –28.5]
[r 28.2] r 28.2 Order for decision (cf SCR Part 31, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Order for decision (cf SCR Part 31, rule 2)

p.text: The court may make orders for the decision of any question separately from any other question, whether before, at or after any trial or further trial in the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 28.3] r 28.3 Record of decision (cf SCR Part 31, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Record of decision (cf SCR Part 31, rule 5)

p.text: If any question is decided under this Part, the court must, subject to rule 28.4, either:
cause the decision to be recorded, or
give or make such judgment or order as the nature of the case requires.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 28.4] r 28.4 Disposal of proceedings (cf SCR Part 31, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Disposal of proceedings (cf SCR Part 31, rule 6)

p.text: This rule applies if the decision of a question under this Division:
substantially disposes of the proceedings or of the whole or any part of any claim for relief in the proceedings, or
renders unnecessary any trial or further trial in the proceedings or on the whole or any part of any claim for relief in the proceedings.
In the circumstances referred to in subrule (1), the court may, as the nature of the case requires:
dismiss the proceedings or the whole or any part of any claim for relief in the proceedings, or
give any judgment, or
make any other order.

There are several bases upon which courts may embark upon the separate determination of issues in the proceedings. CPA s 62(2) permits the separate determination of any factual issue in proceedings. Even apart from specific legislative provisions, the courts retain an incidental power to determine issues separately in relation to the separate trial of questions of fact. That power is simply an incident of a court's power to control its own procedure: Landsal Pty Ltd (in liq) v REI Building Society (now Co-op Building Society of South Australia) (1993) 41 FCR 421; 113 ALR 643 ; Arrowcrest Group Pty Ltd v Gill (1993) 46 FCR 90; 51 IR 270 .

In exercising the power under UCPR r 28.2 , the court must give effect to the overriding purpose to facilitate the just, quick and cheap resolution of the real issues in the proceedings: CPA s 56 ; Ford v Greer [2008] NSWSC 1181; BC200810075 at [25] ; Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Clune [2008] NSWSC 1125; BC200809488 at [6] . The observation has been made that the court should take a more interventionist approach in identifying and separating important issues which can resolve significant parts of litigation expeditiously: Integral Home Loans Pty Ltd v Interstar Wholesale Finance Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1464; BC200611291 at [6] ; Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Clune [2008] NSWSC 1125; BC200809488 at [6] . While courts may now be more disposed to consider ordering separate questions, separate determination is still an exceptional course to be contrasted with the usual course of deciding a case in its totality: Street v Luna Park Sydney Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 697; BC200705558 at [5] ; Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Clune [2008] NSWSC 1125; BC200809488 at [6] ; Bailey v Director-General Dept of Energy Climate Change and Water [2010] NSWSC 979; BC201006518 at [4]–[12] (multiple causes of action — complicated damages assessment — credit issues related to both liability and damages — no separate determination of liability issues); Southwell v Bennett [2010] NSWSC 1372; BC201009029 at [15] (property relationship claim — no separate determination of the existence and duration of the relationship).

Specific orders should be made whenever limited issues are proposed for separate determination and care should be taken to ensure they are really suitable for separate decision: Piercy v Young (1880) 15 Ch D 475 at 479 ; Bottomley v Hurst & Blackett Ltd (1928) 44 TLR 451 . This is particularly so where a question of law is proposed for separate determination: National Real Estate and Finance Co Ltd v Hassan [1939] 2 KB 61 at 77; [1939] 2 All ER 154 at 161 ; Rogers v Bailieu Bullock Wilkinson Pty Ltd (1981) 28 SASR 594 at 598 . Clear formulation of separate questions will properly raise the matter for determination, permit an appropriate judgment or order to be made to reflect the determination, and protect the parties rights of appeal. The formulation of the matter for separate determination can be particularly important in determining whether any appeal from the determination lies as of right or (and more probably having regard to s 103 of the Supreme Court Act) by leave only. Although an order for separate determination can be made to operate retrospectively (American Home Assurance Co v Ampol Refineries Ltd (1987) 10 NSWLR 13 at 18 ), CBS Productions Pty Ltd v O’Neill (1985) 1 NSWLR 601 (amendment of order in the course of an appeal), it may be difficult sometimes to determine whether the matter that has been separately determined is capable of appeal — even by leave. Problems of this sort arise where the separate determination does not result in a specific order. For example, where liability is separately determined, the court is not always obliged to proceed to pronounce any specific order or judgment. If it does not, no appeal will lie: Landsal Pty Ltd (in liq) v REI Building Society (now Co-op Building Society of South Australia) (1993) 41 FCR 421; 113 ALR 643 ; French Caledonia Travel Services Pty Ltd (t/as Connection Holidays) v Elatri (FCA, 22 May 1992, unreported) (separate finding of liability before determination of damages—no appeal). On the other hand, if the court has clearly purported to deal with a matter as a separate question in the exercise of the power conferred by the present rule, an appeal may lie (by leave) even though the court may not have made a formal order reflecting the finding: Landsal , above; Arrowcrest Group Pty Ltd v Gill (1993) 46 FCR 90; 51 IR 270 .

level.toc-caption: [28.4.15] Ordinary position — all issues should be tried together

heading.title: Ordinary position — all issues should be tried together

p.text: The general practice is that all issues in the proceedings should be tried at the same time. Conversely, there is much judicial caution, indeed reluctance, about making orders for separate determination that depart from the general practice. That caution and reluctance stems from the likelihood that the evidence in proceedings will usually be relevant to several issues. There is a risk therefore that the formulation of discrete issues for separate determination may fail to anticipate the full range of the potentially relevant evidence. Where such a failure occurs the proposed separate determination procedure may be frustrated and not result in the intended advantages of saving time and cost: Tepko Pty Ltd v Water Board (2001) 206 CLR 1; 178 ALR 634 at [168]–[170]; [2001] HCA 19; BC200101436 ; Hathaway v Cavanagh (2002) 43 ACSR 497; [2002] NSWSC 1113; BC200206977 .

However, the present rules give the court a general discretion to order separate determination of “any question” in an appropriate case. An applicant for separate determination must satisfy the court that such an order is appropriate in the particular circumstances, but the proper exercise of the discretion is not limited to “special circumstances” as such: Dunstan v Simmie & Co Pty Ltd [1978] VR 669 at 670 ; Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2000] NSWSC 1215; BC200007878 . The proper scope of the discretion, especially in the light of the “dictates of justice” considerations expressed in CPA ss 56–58 encourages courts to take an appropriate role in identifying issues whose separate determination can realistically contribute to the expeditious resolution of proceedings: Integral Home Loans Pty Ltd v Interstar Wholesale Finance Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1464; BC200611291 at [6] per Brereton J, applied by Harrison AsJ in McKenzie v Downing (2008) 50 MVR 1; [2008] NSWSC 69; BC200800619 (order made for determination of issue of liability separately from quantum in motor vehicle accident case). Nevertheless, separate determination is inherently an exceptional course of action: Street v Luna Park Sydney Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 697; BC200705558 at [5] ; Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Clune [2008] NSWSC 1125; BC200809488 at [6] .

Despite the generality of the discretion, practical considerations associated with the potential interrelationship between issues and evidence underline the need for appropriate caution in making any order for separate determination. The criteria in UCPR r 28.4(1) allude to the principal justifications for ordering separate determination — the prospect that claims for relief in the proceedings will either (i) be substantially determined or (ii) become unnecessary to decide, as a result of the decision on the separate question: Love v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1980] 2 NSWLR 112 ; Coenen v Payne [1974] 2 All ER 1109 at 1112; [1974] 1 WLR 984 at 988 ; Dunstan v Simmie & Co Pty Ltd, above, at 671. But the general discretion is available to be exercised in any circumstance where the court is satisfied that separate determination of a question is likely to result in a real saving of expense and inconvenience.

heading.title: Appropriate matters for separate determination — Examples:

p.text: The most usual instances where separate determination is appropriate are:

where there is some preliminary question (of fact or law) that is critical to the disposition of the proceedings (in the sense that if it is decided in one way it will necessarily dispose of the proceedings): Carl Zeiss Stiftung v Herbert Smith & Co [1969] 1 Ch 93 ; CBS Productions Pty Ltd v O’Neill (1985) 1 NSWLR 601 at 606; (1985) ASC 55–407 ; Printing & Kindred Industries Union of Australia v Clark (NSWSC, Needham J, ED No 550/76, 17 September 1976, unreported); Robbins v Royal Bank of Scotland plc [2010] NSWSC 39; BC201000335 (order for separate determination of limitation defence);

where resolution of the separate questions may otherwise promote early resolution of the proceedings or, by narrowing the disputed issues, avoid significant additional expense or delay: Tallglen Pty Ltd v Pay TV Holdings Pty Ltd (1996) 22 ACSR 130 at 141–2; BC9604842 ; CBS Productions Pty Ltd v O’Neill (1985) 1 NSWLR 601 at 606; (1985) ASC 55–407 ; Everett v Ribbands [1952] 1 KB 112 ; O’Sullivan v Challenger Managed Investments Ltd [2008] NSWSC 602; BC200804447 at [16] (proceedings involving numerous parties and common threshold issues); Stewart v Ronalds [2009] NSWSC 455; BC200904500 (separate determination of potentially definitive question of law);

where issues are clearly severable, for example issues relating to liability as distinct from the assessment of damages: see generally [28.4.30] and [28.4.35] (in relation to defamation proceedings) and issues arising under a distinct cross-claim: Admiral 1 Pty Ltd v Leighton Contractors Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1105; BC200509313 , where liability issues depend on the application of contemporary standards of practice and knowledge, and it is desirable, given the uncertain extent of the loss and the possibility of interim payment, to postpone final assessment of damages: Thomas v Oakley [2003] NSWSC 1033; BC200306808 (medical negligence claim as to obstetric procedures for child where assessment of loss not possible for many years);

where the resolution of the separate question is of particular significance and cannot be affected by the determination of the remaining issues between the parties: Integral Home Loans Pty Ltd v Interstar Wholesale Finance Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1464; BC200611291 (entitlement to ongoing payments irrespective of validity of termination of agreement).

heading.title: Matters not appropriate for separate determination — Examples:

p.text: Orders for separate determination are inappropriate where:

the question proffered for separate determination involves the whole subject matter of the proceedings: Radstock Co-op and Industrial Society Ltd v Norton-Radstock Urban District Council [1968] Ch 605; [1968] 2 All ER 59; [1968] 2 WLR 1214 ;
the question involves alternative causes of action or defences: Printing & Kindred Industries Union of Australia v Clark (NSWSC, Needham J, ED No 550/76, 17 September 1976, unreported);

the question may require findings of fact on matters likely to be contentious on the determination of remaining issues in the proceedings: CBS Productions Pty Ltd v O’Neill (1985) 1 NSWLR 601 at 606; (1985) ASC 55–407 ; Murphy v Hilliard [2007] NSWSC 703; BC200705168 at [23] (disputed facts and complex issues of law common to other issues arising in the various claims for relief advanced by both parties);

where the question may involve the credibility of witnesses material to remaining issues in the proceedings (and thus require those issues to be dealt with by another judge): see Australian National Industries Ltd v Spedley Securities Ltd (in liq) (1992) 26 NSWLR 411; BC200402171 ; Century Medical v THLD [2000] NSWSC 5; BC200000171 ; ABB v Freight Rail [1999] NSWSC 1037; BC9906885 ; Langley v AMP Capital Investors Ltd [2007] NSWSC 937; BC200707286 at [27] (credibility of witnesses critical to outcome — heavily mitigates against the separate determination of issues — order refused);
where the parties propose that the question be determined on the basis of limited agreed facts: Windsor Refrigerator Co Ltd v Branch Nominees Ltd [1961] Ch 375 at 396; [1961] 1 All ER 277 .

there is a possibility that the resolution of the separate issue will not finally determine the issue but will merely result in an appeal from that decision in relation to that separate issue, creating a multiplicity of proceedings, interruption to the court and undesirable fragmentation of the proceedings: Story of Sydney Pty ltd v Ling (NSWSC, 15 Nov 1994, Rolfe J, unreported); Century Medical v THLD [2000] NSWSC 5; BC200000171 ; Neumann Contractors Pty Ltd v Wyong Shire Council [2011] NSWSC 481; BC201103420 esp at [22]–[26] and [30]–[33].

The court has power to order that issues of liability and quantum be rejoined and that all issues in the proceedings be tried at the same time: Hoban v New South Wales Land & Housing Corp [2008] NSWSC 1121; BC200809820 at [7] per McCallum J (desirability of early resolution of all issues — damages more readily quantifiable than when separation order made); Warragamba Winery Pty Ltd v New South Wales [2010] NSWSC 66; BC201000549 at [22] (likely substantial duplication of witnesses on both liability and damages issues — potential for conflicting credit determinations).

As a general proposition, questions that turn on disputed facts should not be determined separately: Bass v Permanent Trustee Co Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 334; 161 ALR 399; 73 ALJR 522; [1999] HCA 9; BC9901019 ; especially if the matter proposed to be decided involves “developing” as distinct from merely applying established principles: Woolcock Street Investments Pty Ltd v CDG Pty Ltd (2004) 216 CLR 515; 205 ALR 522; [2004] HCA 16; BC200401482 at [7]. Sometimes the order for separate determination may include provision for the determination of disputed facts: Bass v Permanent Trustee Co Ltd , above at [52]; but this will ordinarily depend on the court being satisfied the disputed facts are within a narrow compass: Jacobson v Ross [1995] 1 VR 337 at 341 ; George Wimpey & Co v Territory Enterprises Pty Ltd [1966] VR 312 . Alternatively, it is often convenient for the factual matters relevant to the separate determination to be the subject of an agreed statement of facts: see Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v Law Society of New South Wales [1976] 1 NSWLR 686 . However, care must be taken to ensure that both the terms of the agreement, and the particular facts, are stated with precision: Bass v Permanent Trustee Co Ltd , above, at [50]. There is a need for particular caution if the agreement is confined to the separate hearing itself because the agreed statement may be falsified in the course of later events in the proceedings. Considerations such as these sometimes indicate the undesirability of attempting to proceed on the basis of an agreed statement of facts: see, for example, Codling v John Mowlem & Co Ltd [1914] 3 KB 1055 at 1063 (agreed facts unlikely to resolve all matters in dispute); Attorney-General v Cobar Corp Ltd (1909) 26 WN (NSW) 49 ; Tooth & Co Ltd v Bryen (1922) 39 WN (NSW) 152; Nissan v A-G [1970] AC 179 at 242 ; Tilling v Whiteman [1980] AC 1 . Similarly, if on the hearing of the separate question (or on an appeal from a separate determination: Tyrell v The Owners of Corporation Strata Scheme 40022 [2007] NSWCA 8; BC200700515 ) it appears to the court impractical to proceed on the basis of the agreed facts, the court may either take such other steps as are appropriate to determine the necessary facts: Wade v Gold Coast City Council (1972) 26 LGRA 349; [1972] QWN 39 ; or refuse to proceed with the separate determination and stand the matter over until the trial: Hume v Munro (1941) 65 CLR 351 at 371–2; 15 ALJR 291 ; Tyrell v The Owners of Corporation Strata Scheme 40022 [2007] NSWCA 8; BC200700515 .

level.toc-caption: [28.4.25] Consequence of separate determination for the remainder of the proceedings

heading.title: Consequence of separate determination for the remainder of the proceedings

p.text: As a general rule, the decision on a separate question of law or fact will bind the parties, subject to appeal, in the further conduct of the proceedings: Fidelitas Shipping Co Ltd v V/O Exportchleb [1966] 1 QB 630 at 642; [1965] 2 All ER 4 ; O’Toole v Charles David Pty Ltd (1991) 171 CLR 232 at 245, 260 and 295; (1990) 96 ALR 1 . But this is subject to the court’s power to permit amendment of the proceedings to raise different issues: see Hockin v Bank of British Columbia (1993) 123 DLR (4th) 538 at 551. It is also subject to the nature of the parties agreement, if any, either as to the facts involved in the separate determination or as to its effect.

level.toc-caption: [28.4.30] Defamation proceedings — separate determination of questions

heading.title: Defamation proceedings — separate determination of questions

p.text: It is often appropriate in defamation proceedings for there to be a separate trial of the question whether the published words were capable of conveying the imputation alleged: Hanrahan v Ainsworth (1985) 1 NSWLR 370 at 372–3 ; John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Foord (1988) 12 NSWLR 706 at 728 ; Krahe v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (1986) 4 NSWLR 536 at 542–3 ; Rajski v Carson (1988) 15 NSWLR 84 at 87–8 ; TCN Channel 9 Pty Ltd v Mahony (1993) 32 NSWLR 397 (any determination made under such an order is interlocutory and is open to challenge on any subsequent appeal against the jury's verdict: David Syme & Co Ltd v Lloyd [1984] 1 NSWLR 346; (1984) Aust Torts Reports ¶80-676). Where a plaintiff relies on the natural and ordinary meaning of the published words, the court may submit to the jury the questions whether the words convey the imputations pleaded and, if so, whether they are defamatory, before any other evidence is given in the proceedings: TCN Channel 9 , above; Radio 2UE Sydney Pty Ltd v Parker (1992) 29 NSWLR 448; (1992) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-200 . But an order for separate determination may be refused where evidence other than the matter complained of may be relevant. Thus orders for separate determination may be refused where evidence of extrinsic facts is necessary to identify the plaintiff as the person referred to in the statement (Consolidated Trust Co Ltd v Browne (1948) 49 SR (NSW) 86; 66 WN (NSW) 7 ; World Hosts Pty Ltd v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1976] 1 NSWLR 712 ), or to give the matter complained of a secondary or extended meaning (Grubb v Bristol United Press Ltd [1963] 1 QB 309 at 326, 328–9 ; Love v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1980] 2 NSWLR 112 ) or where facts have to be assumed for the purpose of the determination of the separate question: World Hosts .

level.toc-caption: [28.4.35] Liability and damages — separate determination of

heading.title: Liability and damages — separate determination of

p.text: Despite both the general practice identified, discussed and illustrated in [28.4.15] and cautionary observations to the contrary (for example, ABB Engineering Construction Pty Ltd v Freight Rail Corp [1999] NSWSC 1037; BC9906885 at [4] ), there are recognised situations where it may be appropriate for questions of liability and damages to be tried separately. For example, separate determination may be ordered where there is a clear line of demarcation between liability and damages issues: Polskie Towarzystwo Handlu Zagranicznego Dla Elektrotechniki Elektrim Spolka Z Ograniczona Odpowiadziolnoscia v Electric Furnace Co Ltd [1956] 2 All ER 306; [1956] 1 WLR 562 ; Dunstan v Simmie & Co Pty Ltd [1978] VR 669 ; compare Pioneer Park Pty Ltd v ANZ Banking Group Ltd [2005] NSWSC 832; BC200506132 (expert evidence likely to overlap liability and damages issues — order refused).

If the assessment of damages is particularly complex, separate determination may be appropriate: Smith v Hargrove (1885) 16 QBD 183 . This may be the case in personal injury matters if uncertainty about the plaintiff's prognosis is best resolved by delaying the assessment of damages until medical conditions have stabilised: Hawkins v New Mendip Engineering Ltd [1966] 3 All ER 228; [1966] 1 WLR 1341 ; Stevens v William Nash Ltd [1966] 3 All ER 156; [1966] 1 WLR 1550; Bulovec v Mealing (NSWSC, Sharpe M, 20 February 1980, unreported); Thiering v Daly [2011] NSWSC 1345; BC201109589 (catastrophic injuries — complex assessment issues — prior determination of basis of assessment likely to promote settlement prospects): see also the discussion and examples in [28.4.15] .

Even aside from these instances the court may order separate trial of liability and damages whenever it considers that it is appropriate to do so: Coenen v Payne [1974] 2 All ER 1109 at 1112; [1974] 1 WLR 984 ; Deeny v Gooda Walker (in liq) [1995] 4 All ER 289; [1995] 1 WLR 1206 (damages including potential liability to future third party claimants); Hexiva Pty Ltd v Lederer [2006] NSWSC 318; BC200602814 at [59]–[60] (breach of fiduciary duty — separate determination of liability where plaintiff potentially entitled to elect between damages and account of profits).

Leave is required to appeal from any separate determination of liability issues: Triden Properties Ltd v Capita Financial Group Ltd (NSWCA, Full Court, No 40539/93, 26 November 1993, unreported, BC9302262); Arrowcrest Group Pty Ltd v Gill (1993) 46 FCR 90; 51 IR 270 ; Landsal Pty Ltd (in liq) v REI Building Society (now Co-op Building Society of South Australia) (1993) 41 FCR 421; 113 ALR 643 .

The order in which the respective parties present their evidence or submissions on the hearing of a matter that is to be separately determined will vary according to the nature of the questions involved. Clearly the plaintiff should begin where there is a separate hearing on liability or where the question, whether of fact or law, is one that the plaintiff must establish in order to succeed on the claim. However, separate determination may also involve questions of law (and sometimes questions of fact) upon which the defendant relies. In those instances the former practices in relation to demurrer provide assistance and suggest that the defendant should begin and have the normal right of reply: Borough of Randwick v Duncan (1904) 4 SR (NSW) 754 ; Stevens v Chown [1901] 1 Ch 894 ; National Bank of Australasia v Morrow (1886) 13 VLR 2 .

level.toc-caption: [28.4.45] Questions of law — separate determinations of

heading.title: Questions of law — separate determinations of

p.text: Separate determination, of a question of law, may be ordered on the basis of the assumed truth of all of the allegations in the relevant pleading: Niven v Grant (1903) 29 VLR 102 at 106 . But the utility of this procedure depends on whether the pleading alleges all the relevant facts: Bass v Permanent Trustee Co Ltd , above at [50]; see also Lubrano v Gollin & Co Pty Ltd (1919) 27 CLR 113 at 118; 26 ALR 76 ; Vacher and Sons Ltd v London Society of Compositors [1913] AC 107 at 125 . A point of law which is likely to be decisive of the proceedings if it is decided in a particular way is an appropriate matter to be separately determined: Carl Zeiss Stiftung v Herbert Smith & Co [1969] 1 Ch 93 at 98 ; Everett v Ribbands [1952] 2 QB 198 at 206; [1952] 1 All ER 823 ; CBS Productions Pty Ltd v O'Neill (1985) 1 NSWLR 601 at 606 ; Windsor Refrigerator Co Ltd v Branch Nominees Ltd [1961] Ch 375; [1961] 1 All ER 277 ; Rogers v Bailieu Bullock Wilkinson Pty Ltd (1981) 28 SASR 594 . For example, a question of the construction of a document may be separately determined if it is likely to be decisive of the liability issues in the proceedings: Gold v Patman and Fotheringham Ltd [1958] 2 All ER 497 at 504. But while the court's ability to order the separate determination of questions of law is undoubted, there are many observations that caution against over enthusiastic use of the procedure. This is because what may at first appear as a pure question of law may in truth involve findings of fact and the drawing of inferences from primary facts that are more properly dealt with at the trial of the proceedings as a whole: Rogers , above; Stephenson Blake & Co v Grant, Legros & Co (1917) 86 LJ Ch 439 at 440 .
